content:
Convert SRT to VTT easily with HappyScribe

On this page you'll learn how to convert SRT to VTT in minutes. We explain what SRT and VTT are, show you where each format shines, and offer step by step guides for command line, Python scripting, Adobe Premiere, and our free online tool on Mac or Windows. You’ll see how HappyScribe’s Automatic transcription, Human-made subtitles, API, Caption generator, and Subtitle editor can speed up the process.

What is an SRT file and where is it used?

An SRT file is the most common subtitle format. It uses simple plain text with timecodes in hours, minutes, seconds, milliseconds, like "00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:10,000". Editors, streaming platforms, and tools like our Subtitle editor read SRT for caption display. If you have a transcript from our Automatic transcription, you’ll usually get an SRT file for quick editing in any tool.

What is a VTT file and where do you need it?

VTT stands for WebVTT and is the recommended format for HTML5 video captions. It starts with the header "WEBVTT", supports notes, CSS styling, and additional metadata. Video teams use VTT for web players and online streaming. Our Caption generator can output files ready to drop into any HTML5 video tag.

How can you convert srt to vtt manually using FFMPEG and Python?

If you prefer manual control, you can convert files with FFMPEG or a short Python snippet.

  • FFMPEG command (Windows, Mac, Linux):
    ffmpeg -i input.srt output.vtt
  • Python script with the webvtt-py library:
    from webvtt import WebVTT WebVTT.from_srt('input.srt').save('output.vtt')

These steps keep your timecodes and text intact. If you need a batch process, wrap the commands in a shell or Python loop.

How do you batch process multiple files?

  • Shell loop (Bash on Mac or Linux):
    for f in *.srt; do ffmpeg -i \"$f\" \"${f%.srt}.vtt\"; done
  • Python batch converter:
    import os from webvtt import WebVTT for f in os.listdir('.'): if f.endswith('.srt'): WebVTT.from_srt(f).save(f.replace('.srt','.vtt'))

Can you use Adobe Premiere to convert SRT to VTT?

Yes, Adobe Premiere can export subtitles in VTT format:

  • Import your SRT in the Captions panel.
  • Select the captions track in the Timeline.
  • Go to File > Export > Media.
  • Choose \"WebVTT\" under the captions format dropdown.

What online tools can you use for free?

You can convert srt to vtt online free with HappyScribe’s web app. Upload your file, pick VTT, and get your download in seconds. You can even combine transcript generation, translation, and subtitle styling in a single place. Or try our srt to vtt API to add automated conversion in your workflow.

Which method fits your workflow best?

If you need full custom integration, try our API. For quick free conversions, use our web app. If you prefer local control, pick FFMPEG, Python, or Adobe Premiere. And if you have multiple languages, our Human-made subtitles team can handle format conversion and translation in one pass.

Ready to convert srt to vtt with HappyScribe?

Sign up for free now and start using our Caption generator, Subtitle editor, and API. Get accurate VTT files in seconds without touching a single line of code.

faq.question: Is it free to convert SRT to VTT on HappyScribe?
faq.answer: Yes, you can use our free online tool to convert SRT to VTT with no credit card required. Just upload your file and download the VTT.

faq.question: What is the main difference between SRT and VTT?
faq.answer: SRT is a plain text format with simple timecodes, while VTT adds a header, notes, and CSS styling for HTML5 compatibility.

faq.question: Can I batch convert multiple SRT files?
faq.answer: Absolutely. Use an FFMPEG shell loop, a Python batch script, or our API to process multiple files in one go.

faq.question: How do I convert SRT files on Mac?
faq.answer: On Mac you can run FFMPEG in Terminal, use a Python script, Adobe Premiere export, or our free web app for quick conversions.

faq.question: Will my timecodes stay accurate during conversion?
faq.answer: Yes, both FFMPEG and webvtt-py preserve your original timecodes and text exactly as they appear in the SRT.

comparison:
Subtitle Format Showdown: SRT vs VTT 🎥

Feature SRT 📄 VTT 🌐
File Extension .srt .vtt
MIME Type text/plain text/vtt
Syntax Differences • Timestamps use commas
• No header line 		• Timestamps use dots
• Starts with “WEBVTT” header
Styling & Metadata 🎨 Basic text only
📋 No metadata 		🎨 Custom voice tags, classes
📋 Region & language info
Browser Support • Needs JS plugin or conversion
• Works in most players offline 		• Native HTML5 <track>
• Wide modern browser support
Positioning 📍 Fixed bottom 📍 Control line, position, size
Common Uses • Offline editing
• DVD/Blu-ray subs 		• Web video players
• Live streaming captions
File Size 📦 Lightweight (no header) 📦 Slightly bigger (header + tags)
Code Snippet 
1
00:00:01,000 --> 00:00:04,000
Hello, world!

WEBVTT

00:00:01.000 --> 00:00:04.000
Hello, world!

Pros & Cons ⚖️

SRT 📄

  • Pro: Very simple to edit.
  • Pro: Small file size.
  • Con: No styling options.
  • Con: Limited web support by default.

VTT 🌐

  • Pro: Built-in HTML5 support.
  • Pro: Styling & position control.
  • Con: Slightly larger file.
  • Con: More tags to learn.

Use this if… 🤔

Scenario Pick This
You need quick text edits on your desktop SRT 📄
You want native HTML5 captioning on a website VTT 🌐
You need styling or custom positions VTT 🌐
You want the smallest file for offline use SRT 📄
